prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for breaking up and kicking my girlfriend out of my apartment because she couldn’t pay rent?
She’s in the mindset that the guy should pay for everything, and against my better judgment I went with it. Any dinner, event, trip, hell even groceries I would help out with. She would pay for something once in awhile, and she would clean my apartment from time to time but I never felt like it was equal. Not that I have anything against paying for things, I believe the guy should pay for most, but there has to be some give and take

Fast forward to June 2018. She moves in my apartment in the city. For six months she’s living rent, bill, and virtually grocery free. Again she cleans but it’s not even. 

Fast forward again to now. We move in together so obviously we’re going to split the rent right? For a couple of months we did. Then the last week of February she tells me she won’t be able to pay anything for the rent due to her own debts and bills. I’m furious and she goes and stays with a friend for a week. I pay the full rent which puts me in a precarious financial situation for my own bills and debts. I was worried I wouldn’t be able to pay some of my own things (I was able to with money left over.) then this month comes. She originally says she could pay a few hundred because again, her own debts and bills. I’m wary but I say ok but you’ll have to pay me back. No real response. We talk again the other night and now she says she can’t pay anything at all again. I say ok so are you going to take care of the rent for a couple of months or pay me back? No because why do I have a boyfriend then?

This was the final straw. I’m supposed to help you out with your financial fires while mine get larger and you’re not even going to help me out when you can? Get the fuck out of my apartment. So once again, and for the rest of this lease, I’m paying the full rent. Paying half of it I would be in good shape. Could pay off bigger amounts in my cards and loans, but now I really have to penny pinch until business gets up again which could be a few months. 

We talked a couple days after this and she said it was a test to see how I would react in a tough situation. Like if she got into an accident or something. I believe this is a very very different situation but maybe I’m wrong and I overreacted 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So the situation is about a breakup because the girlfriend couldn't pay rent. The author says he believed the guy should pay for most things but there should be some give and take. When they moved in together, they split the rent at first, but then the girlfriend couldn't pay her share due to her own financial issues. The author ended up paying everything, which put him in a tough spot financially. He got angry and kicked her out after she couldn't pay again and claimed that being in a relationship means he should support her financially without her helping.

First, I need to consider the expectations in a relationship regarding shared expenses. The author mentions that he thought it's okay for the guy to pay for most things, but there should be some balance. When they moved in together, splitting the rent is common, so the girlfriend not contributing might have been a problem. The author did pay for a lot before, but when it came to shared living expenses, her inability to pay led to conflict. 

The girlfriend's argument is that the boyfriend should handle everything because she had her own debts. But if they're living together, expecting one person to cover all costs while the other has debts might be unfair. The author's side is that he's helping her out, but his own financial situation is suffering. He had to choose between his bills and hers, which led to him feeling overwhelmed.

The key points here are mutual responsibility and communication. The girlfriend might have expected the author to take on all financial responsibilities as part of the relationship, but the author had his limits. When she couldn't pay and didn't reciprocate, the author decided to end the relationship. The girlfriend's statement about testing his reaction in a crisis might indicate she didn't realize how her actions affected him. 

In terms of right or wrong, relationships usually require compromise. If the author had financial expectations from the start and communicated them, then expecting her to contribute makes sense. However, if the girlfriend was in a vulnerable financial position and couldn't meet her part, maybe the author could have approached it differently. But given that he tried to work with her and she didn't contribute at all, leading to his financial strain, his decision might be justified. 

On the other hand, kicking someone out of the apartment over unpaid rent could be seen as harsh if there were no prior agreements or if there was a pattern of one-sided support. The author might be in the right if they had an agreement to split costs and she violated it. But if they didn't set clear boundaries from the start, maybe he's also at fault for not addressing it earlier. 

Considering all that, the author made a tough decision to protect his own financial stability after repeated issues. The girlfriend's lack of reciprocity and communication probably played a role. So, the answer might be B (author not in the wrong) because he's standing up for his own needs after she didn't meet her responsibilities. But I need to check if there's any aspect where he could have handled it better without breaking up. Maybe he could have set clearer expectations earlier or sought a solution together. However, given the situation described, his actions seem like a last resort after her repeated failures to contribute. So leaning towards B.
